text: this is Alessandra Stanley of the New
York Times and if you haven't seen the
final episode of Breaking Bad and want
to this is a good time to watch
something else it's hard to say an
ending is redemptive when the hero dies
and the body count is higher than a
Shakespeare tragedy or to the finale of
Breaking Bad on Sunday night was
surprisingly uplifting for one thing
Walter White finally told the truth
about his life of crime he crept into
his wife scholars house and didn't
insist that he built a meth Empire for
the sake of his family I did it for me I
liked it and that admission won him a
chance to say goodbye properly to his
wife and baby Halle Walt rescue Jesse
and saved his life and even one last
moment of reconciliation with that
wayward apprentice that he loved like a
son most of all Walt succeeded the one
thing that scared him the most failure
several times Walt agonized that he
amassed all that drug money for nothing
because his family refused to take it
he found an elegant solution that was a
twofer he box Elliot and Gretchen his
old business partners into providing a
trust fund for his kids with his
ill-gotten gains and he also scared the
daylights out of them don't move don't
don't dare move a muscle
Vince Gilligan the creator was
determined to tie up as many loose ends
as possible and that included using the
ricin
at long last to kill off Lydia at toxic
but ladylike meta distributor it was
almost too fitting but he laced her
beloved sweetener stevia with a poison
and to make sure we didn't miss the
point the camera zoomed in on her teacup
which clouded up as ominously as the
glass of milk in Hitchcock's movie
suspicions
well deserve to die but the viewers who
stayed with him through five seasons of
murder mayhem and meth have earned a
satisfying ending on Sunday night they
got
you
